subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Are words starting with unstressed _be-_, _de-_ and _re-_ usually in HAPPY set?
msgSnippet: ... The happY set.  What s confusing is that the word happy is no longer a happy example of the happY set, due to happy-tensing, which has in many accents
messageBody:
peter_r_guinness scripsit:

> I just realised that I'm a little confused about the happY set.
>
> Are the vowels in words that start with an unstressed _be-_, _de-_ and
> _re-_ syllable usually in the KIT set or are they in the HAPPY set?

The happY set. What's confusing is that the word "happy" is no longer a
happy example of the happY set, due to happy-tensing, which has in many
accents changed all final happY vowels to FLEECE vowels. (Got that?)
I'm going to rename it the rabbIt set, consequently.

In many accents the rabbIt vowel is indeed like the KIT vowel, but in
some, those with the rabbit/abbot merger, both rabbIt and commA (and in
non-rhotic accents, lettER too) are more like the STRUT vowel. (Of course
this doesn't apply in New Zealand where KIT and STRUT are merged.)

> Till now I've thought that they were KIT set words. The reason this
> matters for me is because in my international QS project KIT set
> vowels are represented with [It] and happY with [Eat].

In my view, the word "happy" and other words with unstressed final -y, -ie
should indeed be written with [Eat] (contra Reid, because happy-tensing
had not yet become standard in his day), but the other words of the
rabbIt set should be written with [It].
>
> eg: _before_ in RP (according to Longman's) -> /bIfO:, b@fO:/
> _beside_ -> /bIsaId, b@saId/
> _depending_ -> /dIpendIN, d@pendIN/
> _despite_ -> /dIspaIt, d@spaIt/
> _regarding_ -> /rIgA:dIN, r@gA:dIN/

These dual pronunciations represent rabbIt and commA vowels respectively;
the second pronunciation is used by those who merge rabbIt=commA.

--
A: "Spiro conjectures Ex-Lax." John Cowan
Q: "What does Pat Nixon frost her cakes with?" cowan@...
--"Jeopardy" for generative semanticists http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
